pages.text: Australian Shepherds have two genes that affect how they look, the B Locus and the merle Gene. The B Locus determines whether the dog has more black or red coloration, while the merle gene determines if they show merle patterning or not.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black coloration, while the 'b' allele creates red coloration. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red gene and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for red pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either red carriers or red puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: Understanding of merle is limited, but from our understanding dogs will either be merle or they won't. Dogs that have the merle trait have a distinctive patchy look. Two merle parents will always produce a merle pup, while merle bred to a non-merle can produce a pup with or without the merle trait.
pages.title: Merle
